awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: Computational Methods for Argument Mining: Extraction, Aggregation, and Generation
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding, evaluating and generating arguments are all crucial elements in the decision-making and reasoning process. Not surprisingly then, a multitude of arguments are encountered and constructed on a daily basis as decisions are made at work and at home, in our social life and in our civic life. In spite of their ubiquity in our lives, most people are not particularly skilled in the interpretation or generation of arguments. At best, making sense of the often massive amount of argumentative online text on a topic of interest remains a daunting task. And while numerous tools exist for representing, modeling and visualizing arguments and argumentative discussions, they are limited by the substantial human effort required to input, organize and annotate arguments for use by the tools. Thus there exists a pressing need for, and this project aims to develop, automated techniques from the field of Natural Language Processing to support all facets of argumentation. This project will have a wide array of broader impacts, including providing other
researchers with annotated datasets and tools for the analysis and generation of arguments, enhancing education through graduate and 
undergraduate mentoring, and promoting STEM education diversity through programs for middle and high school girls.  


This project aims to break new ground in the burgeoning area of argument mining. It develops a collection of computational models that comprise the basis of an argumentation toolkit---methods that can be combined and reused to support a range of argumentation applications. The project focuses on inter-related threads of research covering three critical areas of exploration for computational argumentation: (1) argument extraction---making sense of argumentative text. Drawing upon recent developments in structured learning, techniques are developed to identify the components and the structure of an argument within a single document or single turn in an online dialog. (2) Argument aggregation---clustering the components of argumentative text (e.g. sentences, turns) drawn from multiple documents according to the facets of the topic under discussion that they address. Representation learning methods are proposed to better capture topical content and argumentative styles. (3) Argument generation---constructing coherent arguments via rewriting. A neural argument generation framework with key phrase extraction as an intermediate representation is created to improve interpretation of sentences from different sources. A discourse-aware neural generation model is also investigated as an extension to improve the coherence of the generated text.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project advances the state-of-the-art in Natural Language Processing by developing techniques for argument extraction and argument generation. First, we have developed an argument mining dataset for peer reviews. 14.2K reviews from major machine learning and natural language processing venues are collected. Among these, 400 reviews are annotated with 10,386 propositions, each labeled with the type of EVALUATION, REQUEST, FACT, REFERENCE, QUOTE, or NON-ARG. We further annotate this dataset with argument relations, i.e., support, attack, or no relation, yielding 3,636 relations over 400 reviews. Our dataset has been released to the research community. Second, we have developed the first neural argument generation framework that produces an argument of an alternative stance for a given statement on a controversial issue. We have also studied how to improve the coherence of generated arguments with a novel framework that consists of two decoders: one for text planning---selecting talking points to cover for each sentence to be generated, the other for content realization---producing a fluent argument to reflect decisions made by the text planner. Third, we leverage large pre-trained language models for generating long-form text. We further design a novel generation framework to conduct content selection and ordering as text is produced. Our generation systems produce informative arguments, which are rated as more relevant and coherent than competitive comparisons. Fourth, we design an easy-to-use framework that can facilitate researchers and practitioners to build argument structure extraction models for new domains rapidly and accurately. Our efficient argument structure extraction models can use only half of the target domain training data to achieve better F1 scores than comparison models that are trained over the entire training set. By applying and evaluating these methods on a variety of naturally occurring argumentative text, the research also provides the field with a better understanding of the structure and the language of argumentation.

This project has provided datatsets and software which are adopted for a new natural language processing class development, which has been first offered in spring 2020 at Northeastern University and first offered in winter 2021 at University of Michigan. This course has received high evaluation score and very positive feedback from undergraduate students with different seniority. It also provides advising and mentoring for K-12 students as well as education opportunity for K-12 teachers through presentations and demonstration. 

This project has provided research opporunities and training for 1 PhD student, 2 master students, 6 undergraduate students, and 3 high-school students from underrepresented groups. Especially, three undergraduate students involved in this project are women and two have gone to graduate schools. Two high-school students attend college with a major in computer science or engineering. Four undergraduate students have coauthored papers at top NLP conferences, including ACL, NAACL, and EMNLP. 

The findings help the public understand argumentation and persuasion in general. It also promotes efficient civic engagement. We provide open source resources in the form of data, code, and toolkits that will enable the rapid and easy adoption of our approaches in many communities. These open source resources are accompanied by thorough documentation, Python interfaces, and instructions, to make them easily accessible to researchers from a broader range of fields, such as political science, social science, law, education, HCI, and communications.
